item.description:
YVIO is according to the developers "the best of two worlds".

The 2 worlds they refer to are electronic and board gaming.
YVIO is an electronic console which is the basic requirement for different board games which act together with the components of these.

The console itself is equipped with a lot of little LED-bulbs, an SD-card-slot, a loudspeaker and some expansion possibilities. It is further accompanied by 4 coloured disks which have to be inserted into the playing pawns of the different games. They communicate via remote access with the console.
You have to buy boardgames containing the SD-cards with the gaming software and the traditional boardgame accessories.
The boards of the games contain electronic devices too, and these connect to the console via the disks, called "Yvies".
With every game comes also a so called "Yvio skin" which is laid onto the top of the console depicting the symbols for the keys you have to press to play the game and the action segments lit up by the LEDs.

If you liked the game "Die Insel" from the Ravensburger editors, Yvio is your cup of tea, but it offers much more different options and games.

link.value: Yvio: SpongeBob Schwammkopf Krosse Krabbe Express

name.value: Kod DaVinci, po sledam velikih tayn
Код да Винчи: По следам великих тайн

item.description:
Card game with a field. In game it is necessary to create hiding places and to hide in them relics from other players. Players can open anothers hiding places, and also place in the hiding places of a trap. The board makes hierarchy of monks of secret order.

Game is published under the license for book Dan Brown "The Da Vinci Code".

Game structure: 
Cards: 
Relics - 12, 
Traps - 36, 
Breaking - 36, 
Unexpectedness - 8, 
Professional - 8, 
Score Points - 8, 
Relics - 12, 
Counters of players - 8

Field - 1

item.description:
This game is played on an empty 4x4 board. Each player starts with 24 pieces off board. On each turn, each player must do one of the following actions:
- Drop a stack of 1, 2 or 3 stones into an empty cell.
- Drop any number of stones on top of a friendly stack.
- Move a stack into an adjacent (orthogonal or diagonal) empty cell. However, after the move the stack loses one stone (stacks of size 1 cannot move).
- Move into and capture an adjacent enemy stack of smaller size (so stacks of size 1 cannot capture either). The attacking stack loses the number of stones equal to the captured stack plus one.

All stones return to the players reserves. A player cannot make partial attacks, he must move all the stones of the attacking stack.

Wins the player that makes a 4 in-a-row containing friendly stacks with the same size (like 4 stacks of size 3) or an equal, step-wise increment from start to end of the row (e.g., 1-2-3-4, 1-3-5-7, 2-5-8-11).

The objective of this abstract game is to capture the 4 center spots on the board and hold them for one round.

You use cards to move your pieces over the board and to attack other pieces (moving and attack cards are different). So you are limitied in your options by the cards you draw.

By forming "trios" (three of your stones with different colours) you can make your pieces stronger, but you will slow them down at the same time.

Translated "Kvinnofrågor" means Questions about Womens issues.

Kvinnofrågor is an educational game where two or more teams answer questions about feminism, equality and womens history.

There are one hundred cards, each depicting a person or an organisation. Examples of cards: Emma Goldman, Wonder Woman, Grupp 8, Aung San Suu Kyi, Gerd Brantenberg, Le tigre. 
On the back of the cards are five questions worth different points.

Fifteen of the 100 cards are randomly drawn from the deck and placed with the portrait side up. One by one, the cards are picked up and the teams tries to answer the questions on it. The team with the most points wins the card. When all questions on ten of the fifteen cards have been answered, the team that has won the most cards wins.

Game content:
- Rule sheet
- 100 Cards
- 34 page book with information about the people and organisations depicted on the cards.

This game is right now only avalible in swedish. (januari 2009)

Publishers site:
http://www.athenaspel.se

A simple game suitable for very young kids (Ages 4 and up): you race around the range using a color die. Collect as much animals from the range before the sun sets (or there are no more animals left).

But caution! If you don't build a fence for your animals, the animals might run back to the range.

item.description:
This is a pentacube placement game. At the start of the game, the players choose twelve pieces apiece. They then take turns placing the pieces squarely into the box so that nothing protrudes above the top edge.

Players try to form "reserves," which are holes in the structure that may only be filled by pieces that they themselves hold.

A player who passes is eliminated and loses. Every piece left in the loser's hand counts as a point for the winner, but the other player may continue placing pieces in order to rack up extra points, one per piece so placed.

There are minor variants of this game in the rule booklet for three and four players, as well as a quick game called "Home and Dry" for two through 12(!) players. There was apparently also a separately obtainable second booklet, entitled "Spiele mit Pentakuben," that provided eight additional games and a variety of puzzles that could be built with the pentacubes.

This is a square tile placement game in which every tile has one or more red lines that cross one, two, or three of its edges or vertices. Additionally, each tile has either a yellow or a blue background.

After an initial deal, tiles must be placed so as to directly continue some red line already in play, while alternating the background color from that of the tile whose line is being continued. 
 An extra tile may be pulled from the kitty when the player creates a line of three or more tiles of the same background color, or four or more tiles of alternating background colors. The winner is the last player able to place a tile. There is a non-compulsory scoring system that may be used.

Unlike most other tile-laying games of this sort, the player is not required to place a new tile so that its edge is flush against a previous tile, but can also place a tile vertex-to-vertex, provided that the edges are collinear with the tile whose red line is being continued.

From the publisher's website:

Open the suitcase and discover the world.

An exciting game in which you must win the Paris-Beijing race using your knowledge in geography and as a traveler. Your visual skills and your reflexes will be put to the test. Not a great geographer? No matter. This game can be played by everyone and it will bring you hours of fun.

Contents : board, 165 question cards, 72 country cards, 6 chips, 1 die, hourglass and instructions

Ages 10 and up

A deliberately provocative game that pitches men against women. Each team takes turns to shout out responses to stereotypical topics. It could be "Brands of Make-Up", "Fast Cars", or "Annoying Male Habits". But only answers matching those on the card score points!

Frantic, funny and frequently outspoken, this game pitches brawn against beauty in a contest to determine the superior sex!

item.description:
The Big Score! is a game designed to teach the basics of credit scoring to beginning loan originators, underwriters, and loan processors. It can be played by 2 - 8 individuals or teams.

Each player begins at "Start" with 400 credit score points. Players then move around the board to each category and must answer questions: minimum 50 points/maximum 125 points in each category. Each question is worth 25 points. Players may encounter either Credit Scoring Advances or Obstacles on their way to each category or while in a category. Advances gain points; obstacles lose points. The first player to have accumulated the most credit score points (900 being a perfect score) from EACH category must make their way to "Finish" to win the game.

The game is produced by the United Guaranty Corporation, a member company of American International Group (AIG).

The players must climb the stages of human development from Pliopithecus to Homo Pfifficus. The development is represented by a 12-field-scale.

Every turn the players decide to take 1 to 9 chips in their hands. 
A playing card with a special condition decides which player may move or have to stay or go back after revealing their hands. This card was displayed at the beginn of the turn.

The game ends when one or more players reached the 12th field Homo Pfifficus. These players are the winners.

This game was published in Spielbox issue 6/1992.

Wargaming rules for the American Revolutionary War period 1775-1781. Emphasizes desertion rate, fire & movement and a nearly diceless combat resolution system based on historical unit firepower. Apparently self-published by Ken Ray and Scotty Bowden in August 1974.

In Penalty 2 players compete in an ice hockey match. Both start a third with coins valued 5 (1x), 2 (5x) and 1 (10x).

Every third consist of several duels. The one who reveals the most points by coins in his hand wins a duel and can move the puck up-field. If he can move the puck off of the field he scores a goal.

But if he reveals at least 3 coins more than his opponent he loses the duel and the other player may move the puck.

If one player has no more coins after a duel the opponent can now move the puck according to the number of his remaining coins in order to score a goal. After this, the third ends.

The game ends after the 3rd third. The player who scores the most goals wins.

Penalty was published as Spielbox Edition No.2 in Spielbox issue 2/1993

Answer a question about the time period you are in to roll the die and move through history to win. Start with the Explorers, move on to the American Colonies, then the American Revolution, the Constitution, and finally the Civil War. Each card has five questions, one for each time period.
Match your decimal, fraction, and percentage cards to your spin to turn in those cards. Get rid of all your cards to win!

In this game you have 5 dice (home location [couch, chair and the like], male position, female position, action [touch, kiss and the like], body part). Cast the dice, try to accomplish the position and obtain the most Victory Points.

item.description:
Race Duel S pits two drivers against each other on a variety of different tracks. You must win three races to emerge triumphant but strategic losses will help you extend the competition and win the most Prize Money.

Race duel S includes eighteen track cards that can be used to create five race circuits. Each track card has limits depending on form, weather and condition. Drivers must choose how aggressively they will drive each segment to achieve their goal.

The only thing not included are a D6 die and markers for the record sheets.

Available below in the file section.

item.description:
The Million Dollar Challenge is a new board game based on the teachings of legendary commodities trader Larry Williams, which allows players to enter trades using actual market indicators, such as ADX and Percent R. You'll wait for the correct entry, place your buy/sell order and exit at an opportune time.

This fun and popular board game improves the family's understanding of the many considerations that go into trading the markets.

Begin by moving around the board collecting entry and indicator cards. Determine which market you'll enter by rolling the market die. Markets include gold, T-bonds, wheat, copper, coffee, S&P 500 and more. Wager your contracts, place your protective stop and enter the trade. Watch for changing market conditions. Reach an exit space to determine if your trade is profitable.

name.value: Generals: A trivia Game celebrating the heritage of The Salvation Army

item.description:
Generals is a trivia game about the history of The Salvation Army. Your pawn is an early leader of The Salvation Army. You roll dice to move around the board and answer questions related to the early history of The Salvation Army.

There are spaces which you would draw a "Scalawags or Scoundrel" card. This card asks you a relevant personal question for you to talk about with the other players.

The board is adapted from the illustration that accompanies William Booth's, the founder and first General of The Salvation Army, book, "In Darkest England and the Way Out."

The long-awaited follow up to Luke Morris' 2006 game "Tour", Cycle Free throws the dice out of the window and tears up the race track grids. Instead, up to six team managers will base their strategies on the strengths of their riders, their remaining energy, their daily form and the race terrain.
The focus of the game is on positioning in the peloton, conserving energy and timing the perfect attacks. When the brave cyclists attack off the front of the peloton, the group may be slow to react but as the kilometres go past, and the breakaway group starts to tire, the chase is on!

Tour: Cycle Free is as much an RPG and strategy game as it is a race.

item.description:
Constantly wandering around the warehouse, the rabbits are always ready to snatch away the carrots piled up inside. The farmers cherish their own dear little pet bunnies, but they are furious when other farmers' bunnies come to eat all the carrots they have grown.
Now, the farmers have had enough of it, and have decided to seize all the others' rabbits! But considering that every one of them wants to hide away his own bunnies, will it be that simple to catch others' bunnies? Your goal in this game is to hide away your own bunnies from the other players, and to hunt out the other players' rabbits.

This is a tile placement game with an interesting theme from a Chinese idiom - A cunning rabbit has three warrens. In this game you need to hide your rabbit cards into the farmyard and find out other players' rabbits. However, every turn you need to place a card to the farmyard. Then you can execute two actions. If you use too much actions to trace rabbits, your hand will reduce quickly, but catch others' rabbits is the only way to win.

Home Page: http://embedded.cs.ccu.edu.tw/~mellow/rabbithunt/

item.description:
INCURSION is set in the world of Secrets of the Third Reich and is the ultimate combination of board game and miniatures game. Armored troopers of the US “Lucky Seventh” and stalwart commandos of the United Kingdom’s MI-13 hurtle through underground bunkers and combat the monstrous forces of the German SWD in a furious race against time. The Doomsday Device is ticking and neither the Allies nor the Axis can fail. This two player game features a tight storyline campaign that culminates in an epic and desperate climax. The game mechanics are simple to grasp allowing players to instantly focus on their tactical options. Game play is incredibly fast-paced and tense and players choose their forces through a card-based Requisition Point system. The game is played on a board with a special card deck and highly detailed 30mm metal miniatures. You can also use the miniatures in games of Secrets of the Third Reich. Rules can be found for them here.

In 1946, after stunning German victories on both fronts largely attributed to Vergeltungswaffe 4, a compound that kills painfully and resurrects corpses as dangerous animate objects, Franco joined the Axis. Spanish forces backed by Brandenburger commandos and Fallschirmjager Drop Armor assaulted the British held rock of Gibraltar. Germany claimed the ancient fort with its network of caves and aggressively expanded it into a vast underground research, command, and control center, plumbing the depths of the Rock. In 1949, allied forces mount a massive offensive to retake it. The campaign is bloody and hard-fought but ultimately successful. German and Spanish personnel escape by U-boat from underwater chambers. US and British forces enter the German compound only to be beaten back by the horrors that lurk within the vast twisted labyrinth under Gibraltar. Many commanders feel that the only recourse is to seal the caves from the surface, so that is done. Unfortunately it is impossible to determine the lo cation of all of the undersea tunnels. Zombie naval mines damage or destroy numerous smaller vessels and sink the aircraft carrier Lexington as they sally forth from these undersea caves. MI-13 stumbles onto communiqués detailing German SWD plans for a diabolical Doomsday Device under Gibraltar. Given the effectiveness of previous SWD attacks, the credibility of these reports cannot be ignored. The decision is made to clear the caves. MI-13 Commandos and elements of the US Lucky Seventh invade the stronghold in a desperate race to shut down the Doomsday Device before it can be deployed.

Contents:

Rigid two piece box covered in art
Glossy 28 page rulebook
Card rules summary/playsheet
4 sheets of two-sided heavy-duty die cut pieces (132 total) including counters, doors and stand-ups for all models
Super Heavy duty two-sided six-fold game board
86 cards (66 card Battle Deck and 10 Model Cards for each side)
3 black dice
36 black plastic stand-up holders for doors and "models"
Vac-formed plastic holding tray

item.description:
Welcome to RON and BONES cabin boy:
The most innovative and impressive strategy game of the 7 seas. RON and BONES is a simultaneous cards and miniatures´ game; where long and tedious waits ended between turns.You must prepare your game strategy considering next adversary movements and all boarding chaos. 
Your adversary and you are playing simultaneous strategies so, think quick and over all, hit even faster!! 
Save as much rum and coins as possible to hire your own crew to battle against your adversaries. But be careful! In this game, your enemy can hit you before you have time to draw your sword. Lets your adversary breath away and throw him overboard before he can reorganize his defences, and if you can not do that…bribe his crew!!

Bienvenido grumete a RON AND BONES:
El más innovador e impactante juego de estrategia de los 7 mares. RON AND BONES es un juego de figuras y cartas simultáneo; donde se acabaron las pesadas esperas entre turnos.
Tendrás que preparar tu estrategia teniendo en cuenta los próximos movimientos de tu rival y el caos de un abordaje. Tú y tu adversario jugaréis de forma simultánea asi que, piensa rapido y sobre todo ¡!golpea mas rápido todavía!!
Hazte con mucho ron y suficientes doblones para contratar a tu tripulación y enfréntate a tus adversarios. Pero ten cuidado!. En este juego el enemigo puede atacarte antes de que te de tiempo siquiera a desenvainar.
No des respiro a tu rival y lánzale por la borda antes de que organice su defensa, y si no puedes...¡¡¡soborna a su tripulación!!!.

item.description:
Cymbergaj (pronounced like 'tsim-berr-guy') is a traditional tabletop game that simulates European football (soccer). It was quite popular in schools, the matches took place on classroom desks during breaks between classes.

Each of two players has a team of footballists represented by coins. There's one big coin 'the goalkeeper' and three medium-sized coins 'field players' in each team. To distinguish between teams one of them is 'heads up' the other is 'tails up'. There is also one small coin in use - representing the ball. The goals are usually gaps between two boxes or books each.

The game mechanics is similar to Carrom or PitchCar - players finger-flick their respective team coins to hit the ball and eventually to score points by shooting goals. The rules of fair and foul plays depend on the variant of the game. And the variants are numerous!

In this game players are detectives. They travel around Budapest to acquire every small piece of information. They can make it difficult for the other players by giving them false information. At the end of the game each player writes down his/her ideas about the solution of the mysterious crime; the closest one wins.

There are 30 scenarios given for this game.

item.description: There are two rounds in this game. In the first round players put down hexagon tiles of their color, In the second round they put down white tiles and remove their tiles, and get points according the number of neighbors of the removed tiles. The board, which is made of these hexagon tiles, always has to remain connected.

In this monopoly-type game the result of the dice-roll determines only the direction of the movement on the board (every field has at most six neighbors). The properties are companies and players can only buy shares of the companies.

During the first half of the last century the blood-soaked field of the Far-West, the hunting grounds of the expelled Indians were populated by white settlers. New towns were born, where many adventurers, soldiers of fortune even robbers were living. On the roads public security was nil. Brave travellers, hunters, miners were much threatened. The players drop in to this venturesome world written by Charles May as well. Their goal is to pass through the marked direction at least five to six times amid many adventures and dangers and to gain as many mining, fishing and hunting fields as possible. In the fields where the treasure of the Silver Lake is hidden gold nuggets are found which are brought by the Bank of New Orleans presuming that the player is not robbed along the way. The winner is, who made the biggest fortune at the end. We wish you exciting adventures on the way! (straight from the back of the box)

This monopoly-type game is based on the book Der Schatz im Silbersee (in Hungarian: Az Ezüst-tó kincse) by Karl May. Players can buy fishery, shooting and mining concessions instead of buying properties.

item.description:
Pocket Modern Warfare is a free print and play simple table top game using top down paper minis from Junior General website that can be played virtually anywhere. Using the top down paper vehicles and soldiers from Junior General one can use the terrain available from the site or use any other manner of item to represent buildings and terrain on the table top.

The play is also simplified in easy rulers that are printed with the game that take care of movement and firing ranges. So no tape measures to carry around, just some dice and all the paper mini's you've printed.

For more free great minis visit:
http://www.juniorgeneral.org/

name.value: The Greatest Mission is the World

item.description: The Greatest Mission is the World is a Risk-like in which players control "armies" of LDS missionaries in an attempt to get their missionaries into every country in the world. Players roll dice in battles determine which missionaries will get sent home and collect cards for victory which can be traded for more missionaries. Special interest is paid to Israel as the player who controls that region has access to the 12 Tribes to help win battles.

LDSopoly is a Monopoly style game in which players complete for stewardship of LDS Temples. One player is chosen as the bishop who is in charge of all finances. As players move about the board and "visit the temples" they pay offerings for temples to those who have stewardship over them. The winner is the first to control all temples.

item.description:
Celestialzy (pronounced celestial-zee) is an LDS dice rolling game somewhat similar to Yahtzee but with a few significant changes. Players roll five dice up to three times to score in 12 categories. The dice have symbols instead of numbers that are relevant to the LDS faith.

Sun - The Celestial Kingdom
Moon - The Terrestrial Kingdom
Stars - The Telestial Kingdom
Dipper - The Big Dipper "points the way" to the North Star.
Cloud - Earth (2nd Estate)
Comet - Messengers from God (Angels)

The scoring and categories used on the card are different from Yahtzee with some symbols being worth as much as 25 points per die. Also included are categories for rolling different dice (large and small universe). The player with the highest score wins, unless someone rolls five suns in which case that player wins immediately.

Temples Chess is an LDS Collectible Card Game somewhat similar to Hera and Zeus or a card game version of Stratego. The players have customizable and expandable decks of cards illustrated with an LDS temple and chess piece (which dictates the card's movement). The cards are laid out face down in a 5x4 grid and are revealed when used or attacked. The goal is to find and capture your opponent's king.

Temples CCG is an LDS collectible card game somewhat similar to Magic: The Gathering. Cards feature pictures of LDS temples with indicators of Priesthood Power and required amount of genealogy cards needed to activate the card in battle. Players build their hands from an available 130 cards to have the most Priesthood Power. Kingdom Cards (sold in Booster packs) allow for an increase in Priesthood. Temples that are defeated go to the graveyard until one player emerges victorious.

Christians and Saracens is a low-complexity wargame based on the Battle for Jerusalem. Up to six players can play as an army from the period (Britonian, Franks, or Saxon Crusaders or Turks, Arabs, or Egyptian Saracen). The goal is to break through your opponents' defenses while at the same time maintaining your own. The game is flexible enough to allow one defender the opportunity to beat three attackers (in a four player game).

name.value: How to Host the Greatest Mission in the World Party Game

item.description: How to Host the Greatest Mission in the World Party Game is an LDS storytelling game. Each player fills out a ballot and takes turns telling stories about their LDS Missionary Experience (whether full time or just telling a neighbor or coworker about the LDS Church). After stories are complete, the players use the ballots to vote on the stories. Blue ribbons are provided in the game for prizes.

A word card game in which you lay down and/or add to words from your hand. The unique feature of WinniM is that each card can stand for a vowel or consonant, depending on which end is up. The 105 cards have all possible combinations (5 x 21). This adds an extra dimension: in addition to rearranging letters as you add to your words, you can flip the cards to change the letters in the word. In the Wild version, you can also steal from and add to opponents' words as well.

When the deck runs out and no one can play any more, score for the number of cards you have on the table and for the length of each word, longer words giving many more points.

The gameboard of Finca shows the mediterranean island of Mallorca. Players try to crop and deliver the fruits of Mallorca (such as oranges, lemons, almonds, grapes etc.) by means of moving workers on a traditional windmill. Object of the game is to distribute your crop as effectively as possible in order to deliver faster than your opponents.

From the Box: Mallorca, Island of the Wind. A place of golden beaches and a light-blue sea. The almond harvest is at hand, in addition, juicy oranges, lemons, and figs are ready to be picked and taken to the market. Olive trees bewitch the country with their curled branches and sumptuous vineyards invite passers-by to walk among their warm earth. In the midst of this landscape, your centuries-old natural stone farmhouse provides a home and supports your large windmill: your FINCA.
Listen to the wind, which propels your windmill! Then take in the course of the yearly harvest the sweetest and most valuable fruits from the land. Load them on your old donkey cart and travel around the island, selling them everywhere. If you manage this quickly, you will soon be the richest farmer on the island.

Recommendations:

 2011 Hungarian Boardgame Prize Winner
 2011 Ludoteca Ideale (Italy)
 Nominee "Spiel des Jahres 2009"
 4th place "Deutscher Spielepreis 2009"
 Nominee "Graf Ludo 2009"
 Adult Game of the year 2010 (Finland)

name.value: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing: Counting

item.description:
This GAMES FOR GROWING -- Counting Game Set is designed to help your child learn to count, to learn different ways that numbers are written or shown, and to do simple adding and subtracting. This learning is done in the way that children learn best -- through play.

Includes 3 decks of cards in different sizes, spinners, and a parent teaching guide with teaching tips and rules for 8 different games.

Pas de Charge is a set of rules for Napoleonic Miniatures.
Rules covering the entire Napoleonic period.
Each player in turn pulls its overall initiative to make voluntary movements, spontaneous movements are carried out later.
After shots were fired artillery and fighting Melee.

Bartender is a card game in which players compete to make the most money by mixing fancy drinks. The fancier the drink, the more money it is worth. 
In Bartender, the table represents the bar, the deck of cards represents the store-room full of ingredients, and the cards in the players hands represent the ingredients the players are carrying from the store-room to the bar. 
Players must 'stock' the bar with the cards from their hand so that they can mix fancy drinks but unless they are careful, the other players can use those cards to mix their own drinks.
Bartender was designed as a bartender training aid. 
After a few plays, players will start to memorize the formulas for the over 50 real drinks depicted in the game.

Impacto is a set of rules for WWII Miniatures of 5mm.
The rules are a basic introduction to the game of miniatures.
Sequence of game is typical: simultaneous movement and fire.

Price of Freedom can be played as a pen and paper role-playing game or as a hex and counter wargame. It depicts a conflict between Soviet forces occupying America and resistance fighters.

Expanded by:

 Price of Freedom Gamemaster Pack

name.value: Pokémon Diamond and Pearl Battle Dome

item.description: This game comes in a huge box, and builds up a multi-level tower measuring over two feet tall at 26 inches. The game comes with five different Pokémon miniatures, and players choose which to play. Each level of the tower features a different game usually representing a Pokémon-style showdown, culminating in the top level, where one player takes the cannon while the defending player controls his piece, trying not to be hit.

This game book series distinguishes itself from the other mainstream game books in various ways, adding up to the complexity of the rules and providing a combat system that is very similar to the miniatures combat system as used for instance in "Heroquest". Whenever there is a fight, a map is provided showing where the players and their foes are located, and players must resolve the fight using counters or miniatures.
The series supports up to four players; a single person may play with a powerful character, or a team of four people may play with a diversified group of less powerful characters (a Warrior, an Enchanter, a Sage and a Trickster). When multiple players participate, a single person is designated as the reader, and he or she must read the book aloud to the group; however, at certain points, different characters have to read sections to themselves privately, giving different knowledge to different people.

item.description:
Risk: Halo Wars allow players to command one of three factions (the UNSC, the Covenant, or the Flood) and battle for supremacy of Arcadia. The board features 42 territories and six sectors; 250 plastic playing pieces represent the three factions. It uses the new Hasbro rules that allow for three levels of game play (basic, advanced, and classic) depending on the skill level and desired playing time of the players. Play can be completed in as little as 60-90 minutes with no decrease in strategy. The game is appropriate for Ages 12 and up. MSRP is $39.95.

Re-implements:

 Risk (Revised Edition)

item.description:
Harigana is a tile-laying word game for Japanese for 2 or more players. Tiles have hiragana syllable symbols rather than letters. The game is similar to Scrabble, but has some differences in the scoring system and some other differences to accommodate the Japanese language and the hiragana writing system.

The game was designed with Japanese language learners in mind, but can be played by Japanese speakers just as well. Japanese language learners should not hesitate to use a dictionary to help find words, and are advised to use an optional rule that awards bonus points if they can write kanji versions of words correctly (without looking them up, of course).

item.description:
Amore is a game for word lovers. The deck has 108 cards: in each suit, the whole alphabet plus a second set of vowels; and 4 jokers. Rarer letters are worth more points.

In the main Amore game, players are dealt a 9-card hand, and there are two rounds where each may discard 1-3 cards in exchange for new ones, similar to draw poker. Then they score the highest-scoring words they can find. Finally there is a bonus round, where hands are passed to the right, and those who can find a higher-scoring word than the original owner earn double the difference in points. The game ends when the deck runs out.

There are also rules for Amore versions of Solitaire, Poker, Rummy, and "Crazy Aitches".

name.value: Martial World: The Farm Land Adventures
Martial World: Green Snake Training Card Games
Martial World: Red Dragon Training Cards
The New Martial World Advanced Editions

item.description:
So you are looking for a new type of card game. Maybe you want a to give a great gift, or the kids are way too active and you want to give them something new to do. Maybe you are a student, or a teacher or maybe you just enjoy most everything about the Martial Arts.

Well...

Welcome to Martial World's advanced "Trainers Edition" card game. "World Arts On Playing Cards"

As most, who are familiar with our games know, Martial World is an American style strategy game, which challenges players to win martial arts based sparring matches, using technique based "micro messaged" collectible cards. These combat strategy card games combine point-trick mechanics with card-capturing mechanics for deck building purposes. We call the deck building process "Building Your Form".

Each game box is designed for 2 to 5 players, intended for anyone ages 7 and up, comes with a single magnifying glass, (for a limited time) and no martial arts experience is necessary. Games are easy to learn, easy to develop flexible strategies, and average 90 minutes to establish a winner.

The fun is how cleverly the combination of multiple forms of martial arts technique terms, combine into round robin melees of attacks, blocks, and counter maneuvers. Here's how. Players spar in rounds which are initiated by the role of the dice and the round winners keeps the technique cards to add to their form. Another fun feature for players who are not sparring is that they may enjoy the micro messages which, for the white belt levels, display each school's core principals and values. You may even be surprised that most of these messages can be applied to every day life. So playing has good life benefits.

Ultimately our novel mechanics, embedded surprises, and our school based narrative features, provide players the opportunity to experience the many benefits of martial arts without the Epson salt. All may play and enjoy.

Designer's Note: All of our games are designed based on the history of real martial arts and may include many of each school's or style's myths. However folks, this is a game. Let's be honest, the only way to truly learn any form of Martial Arts is to do research and depending on your ideals, you will find a style which appeals you. Besides that, we are a USA based company and our games are made in America. We were originally published in 1992 but needed a lot of work. We kept pushing and in 2011 we were nominated for the Gaming Genius Awards as the best new card game. We were finalists but needed many upgrades. So we upgraded everything. Lastly we are members of our local gaming group CABS and have a membership with the Patent Tested Parent Approved association.

We welcome all feedback and recommendations. You may also zoom in to all of our pictures for samples of hidden surprises...

item.description:
This game is an electronic game, similar to Battleship made by Radio Shack/Tandy. The game board is set up similar to battleship with an electronic base and a divider to prevent the players from seeing their opponents grid. Each player places 1 ship on their 11x11 grid, with the ship taking up one square. Players have 3 options on a turn, the option of placing sonar markers that indicate the general direction of the opponents ship (N/S/E/W), firing missiles, or moving their ship (a maximum of 5 or 10 units per game, depending on the mode selected).

This a fun game that offers more slightly more complexity then Battleship, and more tense battles, since after 1 hit the game is over.

name.value: Grand National: A Sweepstakes Game of Chance

item.description: Featuring a copyright date of 1937, the box proclaims the game to be "complete with game * board * money * dice * horses * counters" and inside it indeed comes with all those parts. There are four horses -- red, blue, green and yellow -- in this game, which was released by Whitman Publishing Co.

From the publisher: 
This character education game teaches students how a real business works, as well as how employees directly contribute to the success or failure of the business. As the game progresses, profits and sales are affected by the behavior of employees under realistic business conditions. Students will recognize exactly which behaviors employers value in their employees. A fun game that reinforces good employee behavior and introduces common business terms. Includes teacher's booklet and reproducible score sheets.

BRAIN QUEST card game comes with two decks. The Questions deck is like a normal deck of playing cards with the addition of 4 trivia questions on them. These can be used to play variants of Rummy, Solitaire, or Go Fish (instructions included.) The Game Deck is used only with the BRAIN QUEST card game in which players draw from the Game Deck to get instructions on how to play their Questions cards. The first player to get rid of his or her cards wins.

item.description:
From the game insert: "LinguaFun is an exciting learning tool that combines the effectiveness of audio language tapes and flash cards with the fun of many popular card games. From the very first game you play, you will be speaking a foreign language using this unique and proven method. Available in Italian, French, Spanish, German, and Ingles."

The game comes with cards and a pronunciation CD. The cards come in three colors, are numbered with digits and the word for that number in the foreign language, and contain a word or phrase with a phonetic guide and English translation. Rules come for using these cards to play Solitaire, Crazy Colors, Concentration, Gin Rummy, Go Fish, and War.

name.value: Star Wars Clone Wars: Giant Card Games

item.description: A deck of 32 cards, 4 sets of eight characters, featuring cartoon characters from the Star Wars Clone Wars animated film. Four games can be played: Grevious Hunt (Find the Queen); Use the Force (Pairs); Jedi Dual (Snap); and Clones (Rummy ie collect all four characters in a set).

The game contains a board, troop units (cardboard with plastic stands), and loyalty/deployment cards.A rulebook contains 2 pages of rules and some background to the theme.

The Board represents the city of Oja and each player represents a colonel in the Ojawan army. The first player to subdue the Presidential Guard and capture the palace wins.

Each player has 6 units under his command, 4 infantry and 2 tank. One tank will capture one infantry but two infantry capture one tank. Once captured the forces join your team.

However, through loyalty cards, you may find you attack with one of your units who promptly joins the other side as they play its loyalty card.

name.value: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King Board Game

item.description:
One player takes the role of Mordor, and the opposing two to five players represent the Fellowship. Each player has a hand of cards taken from corresponding Mordor and Fellowship decks. The board shows tracks to record the progress of pieces representing The Army of Mordor, Merry and the Rohirrim, Gandalf and Pippin, Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli, and Frodo and Sam. Along the board tracks are seven locations to represent the key conflicts of the movie : Minas Tirith, Osgiliath, Shelob's Lair, etc.

Each player takes a turn to roll dice, accumulating movement points which will allow them to draw a Journey card (again from corresponding Mordor and Fellowship decks), this card then instructing them to draw battle cards, or sometimes to force the opposing side to discard cards. Players must manage their hand of cards bearing in mind the different cards that 'trump' in the conflicts to come.

As each of the locations is reached by the piece moving there, different rules apply to determine the exact course of combat. The goal of the Fellowship is to survive these encounters long enough until Frodo and Sam reach Mount Doom : Mordor has the opportunity to bring an early victory by defeating the Fellowship before the Ring is cast into the fire.

Though this may have a cover similar to The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, this was accepted to the database on the premise that it is an entirely different game.

item.description: Primo the Monkey was fast asleep until his friends swung by for a surprise pajama party! Help Primo chase away the primate pranksters by flipping and swapping cards in numerical order. Watch out for elephants and giraffes who want to crash in on the fun. And if you're lucky, draw a wild monkey card to clear out the room in one clean sweep! The first player to stop the monkey mayhem and get Primo back to bed wins.

item.description: If you’ve ever been inside a photo booth, you know what it’s like to act wild and crazy under the pressure of time. We’ve tried to capture a little bit of that frenetic feeling in this super fast dice game. As you quickly roll dice and look for matches, you’ll not only sharpen your reflexes, but you will also strengthen fine motor skills and visual acuity. Race to the photo finish in this dice game that plays out in a flash! Quickly roll your dice to match the characters on the photo booth cards. When you match a pair, shout "Cheese!" and collect the card. Win all the cards and you're picture perfect!

name.value: Walter Wick Can You See What I See?
Can You See What I See? Finders Keepers Game

item.description: Can you see a seashell? How about a kangaroo? Find both of these and more in this visual game of hide and seek just for you! Reveal a Find Me tile and try to find the featured object among your set of Keep Me cards. Look carefully as objects may be hidden and you may have more than one match on your cards. Be the first player to collect all of your cards and you have one sharp eye!

item.description: Shoot like a shark in this fast-paced underwater dexterity game. But watch out for the slippery Eight Ball - sink it too soon and you've sunk the game! Shoot the most balls into the fish pockets and you rule the pool.

In Catch the Mice players are hungry cats, trying to catch colored mice – but you probably already figured that out from the title.

On a turn, a player rolls the two dice, then "catches" a mouse of the color showing on the dice, assuming the player hasn't already collected that color this turn. If you roll the same color on both dice, you steal a mouse from your opponent! You may keep rolling but if you can't catch a mouse after a die roll, you lose everything. The game ends when there are no mice left, and points are scored for captured mice.

Polar Derby features the same game play as Catch the Mice but instead of mice players collect bears on roller skates, which is completely ridiculous and unbelievable. Bears on pogo sticks, sure, but not roller skates...

item.description: Alta is a connection game played on a diamond-shaped board. An unusual twist of the game is that players place diagonal lines, called "switches," in the squares, which can be slanted either forward or backward. A player can either put a new switch on the board or "toggle" the direction of one of his switches. The object of the game is to connect two "nodes" at opposite corners of the board.

name.value: Disney's The Jungle Book 2 Animal Noises

item.description:
Two family card games in one box.

Game 1. Animal Noises: Turn over the cards and react very quickly by making the chosen animal noise. The first person to get rid of all their cards wins the game.

Game 2. Quartet: Collect 4 cards of the same family as quickly as possible.

a tower in the middle between the two players contain a bunch of marbles.
they roll out of the tower on 2 sticks, the sticks are manipulated by the players, to guide the balls over a filed with holes.
The holes have different points.

Trivia/Riddle game.

1 player reeds a riddle/story
other players try to guess the solution, if not found, a first hint is revealed, ... until 4 hints are given

From the rules:
DEKKO contains a series of SIX new and exciting word card games, all specifically designed to generate improvements in spelling and vocabulary, for people of ALL ages.
The use of a Dictionary is desirable in all games, for, when used in conjunction with the cards, the two produce an extremely powerful partnership for learning.

The games included are:
Penalty
Take-A-Word
Boxwords
Foil
Starwords
Declaration

Claude Soucie's minimalist card game of outsmarting the opponent. A small deck of 10 cards is dealt to two players. One card per player is put face down then revealed. The higher card wins, unless the smaller card divides it evenly, or is one less than the higher. After five tricks the hands are swapped and played again. Whoever takes the most tricks wins.

This game is similar to Pico and Pico 2, but predates both by at least 15 years. It was published in Sid Sackson's Card Games Around the World in 1981.

The ten card deck consists of 2-10 and 12. A longer version can be played with fourteen cards and seven tricks, using 2-10, 12, 14, 15, 16, and 18. A normal deck of cards can be used, with one suit for 2-10 and another for 12 and higher.

Flamingo overboard! Fling your lifesavers as fast as you can to ring them around the flamingos. But be careful where you fling or you'll be up to your neck in alligators! Ring up the most points and win this game of far-out flamingo fun!

item.description:
Basic wargame for two players, set in the Napoleonic period.
Utopian battle with board symmetrical.
The phases of a turn: Firing artillery,Movement and Combats.

[From the box back]

"Time to throw your best combinations and shout out loud. With a little strategy and luck, you'll be the first to get rid of all your cards to win this lively game of pivotal plays. How many times can you Zap? Is it time to Bam? Can you plan ahead to Pow at just the right moment? A game of cards never looked or sounded so fun."

Contents:
60 Cards
3 Start Cards
Rules of Play

In this simple card game, players take turns playing their cards to one of 3 piles, initially in the three suits of Zap, Bam and Pow. When playing a card, it must match either suit or number of the card being played on, with a matching number switching the suit of the current pile and allowing the player to continue his turn. The first player to play out all his cards wins.

From game box inside:
4398 THE THREE GAMES OF PITCH-A-RING CROWN THE KING AND RING TOSS
These games may be played by two, three of four persons.
Directions For Playing Pitch-A-Ring
Remove from the box, and inset the tall post in center socket (wooden post 9" long) of wooden frame (two wooden interlocking pieces 11" long). The player takes his position at such a distance from the box as may be agreed upon, thus bringing one of the four posts directly behind the tall one (4 shorter posts 7" long).
Each player in turn pitches all the rings and endeavors to make the highest score according to the following plan. Each hoop that goes upon the tall posts counts 50, and a hoop on any of the other four posts counts 5. The hoops that do not go on to any of the posts count nothing. The players may take as many turns as shall be agreed upon, each player throwing all the hoops at each turn (4 wooden hoops 6" diameter).
Crown The King
This game is played precisely like the preceding, only it may be placed in any position, and a hoop upon the tall post counts 10, and a hoop upon any of the other four posts counts 5.
Ring Toss
In this game the short posts are dispensed with, the tall post is inserted in the socket in center of the frame. Each player, in his turn, pitches all the hoops. Every hoop that goes upon the post counts any number that may be agreed upon, as 10 for example, while all others count nothing.

"Each player controls a team of 4 Super Fast Hover Cycles. Each player has a set of 4 models that share a unique team color and design. Each cycle within a team is numbered 1 through 4."

"The track length is divided into 100 spaces. The track has a width of a single space. Each space needs to be big enough to hold 1 Tile and several cycles. Multiple cycles can occupy a single space. At the beginning of the track there should be a Start Zone."

A set of 100 Terrain Tiles are randomly distributed randomly to form a different track for each game. The set consists of 5 tiles for each of the twenty terrain types. Despite their name, the Terrain Tiles have a number of different abstract effects on gameplay and are not all named to describe different types of terrain.

Two decks of standard playing cards are also required to play.

Points are scored based on the order in which a cycle reaches the finish line. The player scoring the most points wins.

name.value: Raleigh Burner Freestyle BMX Card Game

item.description:
Description from the box:

"BMX is one of the fastest growing sports today. Not everyone can get to race on a BMX track but with care and skill can learn many freestyle "tricks" almost anywhere. You don't even have to own a BMX bike to play this game, but if you do, playing it will show by "stop action" sequence: Wheelies, Endos, Pogos, Buckin' Broncos, Kickturns and lots more. The winner is the player who "performs" by collecting the most sets of freestyle "tricks".

The game is back by the people who should know - Raleigh and their BMX Factory Team. Get to know your Pogos from your Endos!"

name.value: Kids Say the Darndest Things! Family Game

item.description:
Based on the hit TV show starring Bill Cosby and classic segments from Art Linkletter's "House Party" program, the Kids Say the Darndest Things Game takes the most outrageous comments made by kids and puts them in a game that the whole family can play.

Players are read a question straight from the Kids Say show and then read four possible answers. It's your job to choose which response was actually given on National TV. As you move around the board, you may also land on "Hot Seat" spaces that will put you on the spot to fill in the missing words from a Kids Say response.

Players score their correct answers on a Bill Cosby scorecard. The first player to completely uncover Cosby wins the game.
Simple roll and move game, the object being to get your elephants through the SHADY, HAPPY and SUNNY Jungles and to the finish line which is the HOME OF THE PEANUT.

A set of miniatures rules to allow players to recreate the great battles of the Age of Napoleon. Infantry, cavalry, and artillery all clash on the tabletop, under the command of historical military personalities with individual ratings.

Scale is set to about 120 men per figure. 1" is 100 yards. Figures are grouped to represent brigades and regiments.

Napoleon's Battles (third edition) has been upgraded to a 100 page rules book, 56 page reference book, 12 scenarios and over 180 status cubes and markers.

This is a game conceived by Kreeda, and is a sequel to Vanavas. In the Indian epic - the Ramayana, Dasharatha, Rama's father is forced by an old promise to send Rama, his eldest son away to the forest for fourteen years. Rama is accompanied by his wife Sita and brother, Lakshmana. Vanavaas - The Adventures in the Forest follows their experiences until the kidnapping of Sita.

In this game, you follow the adventures of Rama and Lakshmana as they Search for Sita and seek the help of the vanaras or monkeys.
